Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Situation2: They plan to attend a family ceremony, making sure to arrive on time and wear appropriate attire.
Story: I glanced at my phone, a message from my sister lighting up the screen: “Movie night with friends at 7? You promised!” My heart sank. I had promised, and I knew how much it meant to her that I include her in my life, that we build the kind of mutual respect and closeness we’d always talked about. But as I looked at the clock, I remembered the family ceremony tonight—an important Hindu puja that my parents had been preparing for all week. They expected me to be there, dressed in traditional clothes, on time, to participate fully in the rituals. I could almost hear my mother’s voice, reminding me how important it was to honor our traditions, especially during festivals. My mind raced, torn between the warmth of my sister’s anticipation and the weight of my family’s expectations. I wanted to be a good brother, to make her feel included, but I also felt the pull of my faith and the responsibility to my family. The two worlds pressed in on me, and I sat frozen, unable to decide which promise to keep.
